In the [[Quanzhou dialect|Quanzhou]] variant of Southern Min, it is the sonorants that were voiced and in the rising tone in Middle Chinese that have split. In literary pronunciations they have merged into tone {{lang|zh|③}}, but they have become tone {{lang|zh|④}} in colloquial pronunciations. :‡ In the Quanzhou Hokkien variety of Southern Min, the traditional 'light' and 'dark' departing tone categories are only differentiated by their behavior under [[tone sandhi]]; they are pronounced the same in isolation. :‖ Some studies show that in Hong Kong Cantonese the two rising tones are used interchangeably by some younger speakers indicating an ongoing merger,{{Cite web|url=https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Perception-of-the-merging-tones-in-Hong-Kong-Pik-Ki-Wong/a67cdf9aca2ad93fa45ecf1e60b3ed827b88c3a1|title=Perception of the merging tones in Hong Kong Cantonese: preliminary data on monosyllables - Semantic Scholar|website=www.semanticscholar.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-11}}{{Cite journal|last=Bauer|first=Robert S.|last2=Kwan-hin|first2=Cheung|last3=Pak-man|first3=Cheung|date=2003-07-01|title=Variation and merger of the rising tones in Hong Kong Cantonese|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/language-variation-and-change/article/variation-and-merger-of-the-rising-tones-in-hong-kong-cantonese/CD005F4E66BA63AF2A4AD8BFB5E822E5|journal=Language Variation and Change|volume=15|issue=2|pages=211–225|doi=10.1017/S0954394503152039|issn=1469-8021}} but this is in fact extremely uncommon. :'''◊''' A lexical tone change. High Level becomes High Falling when the character isn't used as a concrete noun. ==See also== * [[Four tones (Chinese)|Four tones of Standard Mandarin]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |last=Branner |first=David Prager (ed.) |title=The Chinese Rime Tables: Linguistic Philosophy and Historical-Comparative Phonology |series=Studies in the Theory and History of Linguistic Science, Series IV: Current Issues in Linguistic Theory; 271 |year=2006 |publisher=John Benjamins |location=Amsterdam |isbn=90-272-4785-4 }} {{refend}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Four Tones}} [[Category:Phonetics]] [[Category:Chinese language]] [[Category:Middle Chinese]]

'''Grammelot''' (or '''gromalot''')<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9gTs9xWJcgg|title=Commedia dell'Arte: Language|first=|last=National Theatre Discover|date=6 October 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> is a style of language used in satirical theatre, a [[gibberish]] with [[Macaronic language|macaronic]] and [[onomatopoeia|onomatopoeic]] elements, used in association with [[mime]] and [[mimicry]]. The satirical use of such a format may date back to the 16th century [[commedia dell'arte]]; the group of cognate terms appears to belong to the 20th century.
==History==
In an essay entitled “L’art du grommelot” (Le Figaro, April 20, 2006), French scholar Claude Duneton suggests the word (not the technique) – in its French form, ''grommelot'' – has its origins in the ''commedia dell’arte''-derived Italian theatre of the early part of the sixteenth century. Duneton studied briefly with Léon Chancerel (1886–1965), who was a major figure in this branch of theatre. Chancerel in fact uses the word in his book, ''Le théâtre et la jeunesse'' (Paris: Bourrellier 1946:47). Others, such as theatre scholar John Rudlin in ''Commedia dell'arte: An Actor's Handbook'' (London: Routledge 1994:60), suggest this origin as well.
While the historical origin of the term is unclear, it has been particularly popularized by the [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]]-winning Italian [[playwright]] [[Dario Fo]]. His 1969 show ''[[Mistero Buffo]]'' ("''Comic Mystery Play''") was a satirical touring performance involving sketches based on mediaeval sources, told in Fo's own grammelots constructed from archaic [[Po Valley]] dialects and [[phoneme]]s from modern languages (he has coined separate Italian, French and American grammelots). In his Nobel lecture, Fo referred to the 16th-century Italian playwright [[Angelo Beolco|Ruzzante]]'s invention of a similar language based on Italian dialects, Latin, Spanish, German and onomatopoeic sounds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1997/fo-lecture.html|title=Dario Fo - Nobel Lecture: Against Jesters Who Defame and Insult|publisher=}}</ref>
Another notable modern Italian exponent is the [[Milan]] actor/writer [[Gianni Ferrario]].<ref>[http://www.grammelot.com/eng_eng/ Grammelot.com], Gianni Ferrario</ref> [[Voice actor]] [[Carlo Bonomi]], also from Milan, used grammelot to voice [[Osvaldo Cavandoli]]'s cartoon [[La Linea (TV series)|La Linea]] and many years later, outside of Italy, [[Otmar Gutmann]]'s [[Pingu]]. Mainstream [[comedian|comics]] have also used Grammelot-like language: for instance, [[Stanley Unwin (comedian)|Stanley Unwin]]. The Canadian [[circus]] and entertainment troupe [[Cirque du Soleil]] uses in its routines similar forms of language; journalists often term them "Cirquish",<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/05/04/arts/theater-cirque-du-soleil-aiming-too-high.html Cirque Du Soleil: Aiming Too High?], Polly Shulman, Teatroenmiami.com</ref> but Cirque du Soleil's own staff use the word "Grommelot".<ref>Section 2, question 13: http://www.cirquedusoleil.com/fr/jobs/casting/faq.aspx{{dead link|date=August 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Pingu]]'' * ''[[La Linea (TV series)|La Linea]]'' * [[Simlish]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070513082011/http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/moveabletype/mt-search.cgi?IncludeBlogs=2&search=Grammelot Language Log: all mentions of "Grammelot"] *[http://itre.cis.upenn.edu/~myl/languagelog/archives/003872.html Language Log: discussion of the mistaken attribution to Fo] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLNGH0XjfeE Dario Fo performing the grammelot of different emotions] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071008090507/http://alexthejester.com/html/grammelotPopup.html A short glossary of Grammelot phrases as used by "Alex the Jester"]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox college |image=Indraprastha College for Women 2006 stamp of India.jpg |caption=2006 stamp dedicated to Indraprastha College for Women | name= Indraprastha College for Women | motto= "Truth Love Knowledge Service" | established= 1924 |academic_affiliation = [[University of Delhi]] | principal=Dr Babli Moitra Saraf{{cite web |url=http://www.ipcollege.com/collegefaculty.htm |title=Faculty |publisher=Ipcollege.com |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100105123220/http://www.ipcollege.com/collegefaculty.htm |archive-date=5 January 2010 |dead-url=yes }} | enrollment= over 2200 | location= Civil Lines, [[Delhi]] | nickname= IP | campus= {{convert|21|acre|m2}} | affiliations= University of Delhi | website= [http://ipcollege.du.ac.in/ ipcollege.du.ac.in]
[http://ipcollege.ac.in/ ipcollege.ac.in] }} '''Indraprastha College for Women''' also known as '''Indraprastha College''' or '''IP College''' ({{lang-hi|इंद्रप्रस्थ महिला कॉलेज}})[http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=28314 Music fest at Indraprastha College held] [[Indian Express]], 3 September 2002. is the oldest [[women's college]] in [[Delhi]]. Established in 1924, it is affiliated to [[University of Delhi]].[http://www.du.ac.in/collegedetails.htm?college_name=Indraprastha+College+for+Women Indraprastha College for Women] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090423102856/http://du.ac.in/collegedetails.htm?college_name=Indraprastha%20College%20for%20Women |date=23 April 2009 }} [[University of Delhi]] Website.''Women, education and politics: the women's movement and Delhi's Indraprastha College'', by Meena Bhargava, Kalyani Dutta. Oxford University Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-19-566911-8}}. ''Page 9''.{{cite web|url=http://www.india9.com/i9show/Indraprastha-College-for-Women-16944.htm |title=Indraprastha College for Women |publisher=India9.com |date=14 October 2005 |accessdate=20 February 2011}} The college offers graduate and post-graduate courses in [[Economics]], [[Liberal arts education|Liberal Arts]], [[Commerce]], [[Literature]], [[Computer science|Computer Science]], Multimedia Media & [[Mass communication|Mass Communication]] etc., and is among the prestigious colleges of India.[http://www.educationinfoindia.com/prestigious.htm The Premier Colleges of India] www.educationinfoindia.com.{{ cite news|title=Top colleges in India: Details, seats and cut-off percentages|url=https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/top-colleges-in-india--details--seats-and-cut-off-percentages.html?page=all|newspaper=[[India Today]]|location=[[Yahoo!]]|date=13 June 2012 }}{{ cite news|title=DIRECTORY OF BEST COLLEGES 2015: ARTS|url= http://indiatoday.intoday.in/bestcolleges/2015/readyrecnor_directory_list.jsp?Y=2015&ST=Arts|newspaper=[[India Today]] }}{{ cite news|title=DIRECTORY OF BEST COLLEGES 2015: COMMERCE|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/bestcolleges/2015/readyrecnor_directory_list.jsp?Y=2015&ST=Commerce|newspaper=[[India Today]] }} ==History== The origins of IP College lie in the Indraprastha Girls School. It was founded in 1904, at the call of noted freedom fighter, educationist and theosophist [[Annie Besant]] by a group of Delhi [[theosophists]], led by Lala Jugal Kishore, in Chhipiwara, [[Old Delhi]]. [[Intermediate school]] was added in 1924 and the Indraprastha College for Women, came into being, with Leonora Gmeiner (from Kapunda, [[South Australia]]) as its first principal.''Delhi, the emperor's city: rediscovering Chandni Chowk and its environs'', by Vijay Goel. Published by Lustre Press, 2003. {{ISBN|81-7436-240-1}}.[http://www.dawn.com/weekly/books/archive/061126/books8.htm REVIEWS: Cognisant Indian women] [[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]], 26 November 2006.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/FullcoverageStoryPage.aspx?sectionName=IndiaSectionPage&id=0fb30b5d-de84-4b4f-9b0c-79e393e7d804Whatafter12th_Special&Headline=IP+college+for+women IP college for women]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[Hindustan Times]]'', 7 June 2007. Soon the [[University of Delhi]], which itself was founded in 1922, recognised it as a constituent college. Degree courses were introduced in 1930s and in 1938, the University recognised I.P. College as a degree college. After its existence in Chhipiwara during its early years, the college moved to Chandrawali Bhawan, [[Civil Lines]]. It moved again to Alipur House at Alipur Road (now Sham Nath Road), the former office of the commander-in-chief in 1938, near [[Kashmiri Gate (Delhi)|Kashmiri Gate]], where it is today. The building has become a heritage property.{{Cite web |url=http://www.delhilive.com/indraprastha-college-for-women |title=Indraprastha College for Women |access-date=7 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080610161313/http://www.delhilive.com/indraprastha-college-for-women |archive-date=10 June 2008 |dead-url=yes }} In 1952, the Kalavati Gupta Hostel (named after a former principal) was established.{{fact|date=June 2018}} It houses 200 students.{{fact|date=June 2018}} On 3 July 1984, Diamond Jubilee celebrations of the college were held''Women in India & Japan: A Comparison'', by Ramesh Madan. Published by Manak Publications, 2004. {{ISBN|81-7827-099-4}}. ''Page 123''. In 2009, a hostel to accommodate 200 students was added on the {{convert|1.53|acre|m2|adj=on}} college premises.[http://www.hindu.com/2009/06/03/stories/2009060360870300.htm I P College gets a second hostel], ''[[The Hindu]]'', 3 June 2009. ==Student life== Indraprastha College is the only college of [[University of Delhi|Delhi University]] to offer the Bachelor in Mass Media and Mass Communication (BMMMC) degree. In 2005, the college added The cyber cafe wing with offices of [[National Service Scheme]] ([[National Service Scheme|NSS]]) and [[National Cadet Corps (India)|National Cadet Corps]] ([[National Cadet Corps (India)|NCC]]).[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2005-06-15/delhi/27836241_1_cyber-cafe-new-courses-hostel IP College set for hi-tech makeovers] [[The Times of India]], 15 June 2005. In 2014, IP College became one of the first in the University of Delhi to set up a formal Department of Environmental Studies, which is its youngest department.{{Cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/a/ip.du.ac.in/environmental-studies/home|title=Environmental Studies|website=sites.google.com|access-date=17 September 2016}} Every autumn, the college celebrates its annual festival, 'Shruti'.[http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=146690 ...students of Indraprastha College are preparing for annual fest ' Shruti '.] [[Indian Express]], 2 September 2005.[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2002/20021206/ncr2.htm Shruti 2002] [[The Tribune (Chandigarh)|The Tribune]], 6 December 2002. Other popular events include the annual debating tournament 'Vivaad' organised by the English debating society{{ cite news|title= Indraprastha College for Women announces Vivaad'13|url=http://www.coolage.in/2012/12/14/indraprastha-college-for-women-announces-vivaad13/|newspaper= www.coolage.in|date= 14 December 2012 }} and the annual theatre fest 'Kirdaar' organised by {{One source|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox Academic Conference | history = 2000– | discipline = [[Computational Linguistics]], [[Natural Language Processing]], [[Human Language Technologies]] | abbreviation = CICLing | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] [[Lecture Notes in Computer Science|LNCS]] | country= International | frequency = annual }}
'''CICLing''' (International Conference on Computational Linguistics and Intelligent Text Processing; before 2017 known under the name International Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics) is an annual [[Meeting|conference]] on [[computational linguistics]] (CL) and [[natural language processing]] (NLP). The first CICLing conference was held in 2000 in [[Mexico City]]. The conference is attended by one to two hundred of NLP and CL researchers and students every year. As of 2017, it is ranked within top 20 sources (conferences and journals) on computational linguistics by [[Google Scholar]].<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=top_venues&hl=en&vq=eng_computationallinguistics Google Scholar computational linguistics category]</ref> Past CICLing conferences have been held in Mexico, Korea, Israel, Romania, Japan, India, Greece, Nepal, Egypt, Turkey, and Hungary; the 2018 event will be held in Vietnam.
== Overview == CICLing is a series of annual international conferences devoted to [[computational linguistics]] (CL), [[natural language processing]] (NLP), [[human language technologies]] (HLT), natural-language [[human-computer interaction]] (HCI), as well as [[speech processing]] and [[speech recognition]] (SR).
Their topics of interest include, but are not limited to: [[text processing]], [[computational morphology]], [[Tag (metadata)|tagging]], [[stemming]], [[syntactic analysis]], [[parsing]] and [[shallow parsing]], [[chunking (computational linguistics)|chunking]], recognizing [[textual entailment]], [[ambiguity resolution]], [[Semantic analysis (machine learning)|semantic analysis]], [[pragmatics]], [[lexicon]], [[lexical resources]], [[dictionary|dictionaries]] and [[machine-readable dictionary|machine-readable dictionaries]] (MRD), [[grammar]], [[anaphora resolution]], [[word sense disambiguation]] (WSD), [[machine translation]] (MT), [[information retrieval]] (IR), [[information extraction]] (IE), [[document handling]], [[document classification]] and [[text classification]], [[text summarization]], [[text mining]] (TM), [[opinion mining]], [[sentiment analysis]], [[plagiarism detection]], and [[spell checking]] ([[spell checking|spelling]]).
CICLing series was founded in 2000 by [[Alexander Gelbukh]].<ref name="CICLing2000" /> The acronym "CICLing" refers to "'''C'''onference on '''I'''ntelligent text processing and '''C'''omputational '''Ling'''uistics", the name used before 2017.<ref name="CICLing2000" />
Almost all CICLing events have been endorsed by the [[Association for Computational Linguistics]].
Unlike some other conferences on computational linguistics and natural language processing, such as those run by the [[Association for Computational Linguistics]], CICLing does not release its main proceedings as [[Open Access]], publishing them instead with [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]]; however, most of its complementary proceedings, published as special issues of journals, are released as Open Access; in addition, Springer allows the authors to make their papers available via their own webpages.

[http://www.thetandd.com/news/local/article_006f53da-d7d6-11df-9521-001cc4c03286.html "A Pioneer, a Visionary": United Methodist Bishop Thomas leaves extraordinary legacy]. Retrieved 2010-10-16.) was an [[United States|American]] [[bishop]] in [[The Methodist Church (USA)|The Methodist Church]] (now The [[United Methodist Church]]). When elected in 1964, he was one of the youngest Methodist bishops. Gerald Kennedy was age 40 when he was elected in the mid-1940s. His first appointment as Bishop was in [[Iowa]], where he served from 1964 to 1976, becoming the first black bishop of the North Central Jurisdiction of The Methodist Church. He last served as the [[Resident Bishop]] of the [[East Ohio Conference]] of The [[United Methodist Church]] from 1976 until 1988, retiring in 1988. In 2002, the [[Iowa General Assembly|Iowa Senate]] passed a resolution honoring Bishop Thomas. In its citation, the Senate extended :"its thanks and congratulations to Bishop James S. Thomas and his family for their service to The United Methodist Church and to the State of Iowa, and acknowledges the work of Bishop James S. Thomas for the advancement of [[civil rights]] in Iowa and in the nation." The resolution was presented to Bishop Thomas on his birthday in the same year.[http://www.legis.state.ia.us/GA/79GA/Legislation/SR/00100/SR00136/Current.html Iowa Senate Resolution S.R. 136 of 2002] ==See also== *[[List of Bishops of the United Methodist Church]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050625030529/http://umc.org/umns/photos_headshots.asp?ptid=2&mid=2060&photo=hst316 Photo of Bishop Thomas] {{s-start}} {{s-rel}} {{succession box | title = [[Resident Bishop]], [[Ohio East Area]], [[United Methodist Church]] | years = 1976–1988 | before = [[Francis Enmer Kearns]] | after = [[Edwin Charles Boulton]]}} {{s-end}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Thomas, James Samuel}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American United Methodist bishops]] [[Category:African-American Methodist clergy]] [[Category:American Methodist clergy]] [[Category:United Methodist bishops of the North Central Jurisdiction]] [[Category:Methodist bishops of the Central Jurisdiction]] [[Category:African-American studies scholars]] {{Methodism-bishop-stub}} {{US-reli-bio-stub}}

'''Kalbelia''' or '''Kabeliya''' is one of the most sensuous dance forms of [[Rajasthan]], performed by a tribe of the same name.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indianfolkdances.com/kalbelia-folk-dances-of-rajasthan.html |title=Kalbelia Folk Dances of Rajasthan }}</ref> They are famous for their dance which is an integral part of their culture. Both men and women in the tribe participate in this activity to celebrate joyful occasionally
==Kalbelia tribe== [[File:Rajasthan folk dance.jpg|thumb|A Rajasthani folk dance, Kalbelia]] The Kalbelias were known for their frequent movement from one place to another in ancient times. Their traditional occupation is catching snakes and trading [[snake venom]]. Hence, the dance movements and the costumes of their community bear a resemblance to that of the serpents. They are also known as Sapera, Jogira or yogi. They trace their ancestry from Kanlipar, the 12th disciple of Guru [[Gorakshanath|Gorakhnath]]. The largest number of the population of Kalbelias is in [[Pali district]], then [[Ajmer]], [[Chittorgarh]] and [[Udaipur district]]. They live a [[nomadic]] life and belong to the [[scheduled tribes]].<ref>{{cite book|title=People of India Vol. XXXVIII|author1=Kumar Suresh Singh |author2=B. K. Lavania |author3=D. K. Samanta |author4=S. K. Mandal |author5=N. N. Vyas |author6=Anthropological Survey of India |article=Suthar|pages=1012|publisher=Popular Prakashan}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Snake Charmers: The Jogi Nath Kalbelias of Rajastan|author=Miriam Robertson|pages=323|publisher=Illustrated Book Publishers|year=1998|ISBN=81-85683-29-8}}</ref>
Traditionally, Kalbelia men carried cobras in [[Arundo|cane]] baskets from door to door in villages while their women sang and danced and begged for alms. They revere the [[cobra]] and advocate non-killing of the reptile. In the villages, if a snake inadvertently entered a home, then a Kalbelia would be summoned to catch the serpent and to take it away without killing it. Kalbelias have traditionally been a fringe group in society living in spaces outside the village where they reside in makeshift camps called ''deras''. The Kalbelias move their ''deras'' from one place to another in a circuitous route repeated over time. Over the generations, the Kalbelias acquired a unique understanding of the local flora and fauna, and are aware of [[herbal remedies]] for various diseases which is an alternative source of income for them.
Since the enactment of the [[Wildlife Act of 1972]], the Kalbelias have been pushed out of their traditional profession of snake handling. Today, performing arts are a major source of income for them and these have received widespread recognition within and outside India. However, performance opportunities are sporadic and since the whole community is not involved in it on a regular basis, many members of the community work in the fields, or graze cattle to sustain themselves.<ref name="unesco"/>
==Kalbeliya Dance== The Kalbelia dance, performed to celebrate any joyful moment in the community, is an integral part of Kalbelia culture. Their dances and songs are a matter of pride and a marker of identity for the Kalbelias and they represent the creative adaptation of this community of snake charmers to changing socioeconomic conditions and their own role in rural [[Rajasthani people|Rajasthani]] society.
The dancers are women in flowing black skirts who dance and swirl, replicating the movements of a serpent. The upper body cloth is called ''Angrakhi'' and a piece of cloth worn on head known as ''Odhani'' similarly the lower body cloth is called ''Lengha''. All these cloths are mixed in red and black hues and embroidered in such a way that when these dancers perform these clothes represent a combination of colours soothing to eyes as well as to the atmosphere.
The male participants take care of the musical part of the dance. They use the different instruments such as the [[pungi]], a woodwind instrument traditionally played to capture snakes, the [[daf|dufli]], [[pungi|been]], the [[khanjari]] - a percussion instrument, [[morsing|morchang]], ''khuralio'' and the [[dholak]] to create the rhythm on which the dancers perform. The dancers are tattooed in traditional designs and wear jewelry and garments richly embroidered with small mirrors and silver thread. As the performance progresses, the rhythm becomes faster and faster and so does the dance.<ref name="unesco">http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/index.php?lg=en&pg=00011&RL=00340</ref>
Kalbelia songs are based on stories taken from folklore and mythology and special dances are performed during [[Holi]]. The Kalbelia have a reputation for composing lyrics spontaneously and improvising songs during performances. These songs and dances are part of an oral tradition that is handed down generations and for which there are neither texts nor training manuals. In 2010, the Kalbelia folk songs and dances of [[Rajasthan]] were declared a part of its [[Intangible Heritage List]] by the [[UNESCO]].<ref name="unesco"/>

'''Language acquisition by deaf children''' parallels the development of any children acquiring spoken language as long as there is full access to language from birth.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} Despite limited access to spoken language, communication and language exposure are fundamental to deaf infants' general cognitive development and their engagement with their surroundings. While a growing number of deaf children in the developed world receive hearing aids and/or cochlear implants to support spoken language acquisition<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Bradham|first1=Tamala|last2=Jones|first2=Julibeth|title=Cochlear implant candidacy in the United States: Prevalence in children 12 months to 6 years of age|journal=International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology|date=July 2008|volume=72|issue=7|pages=1023–1028|doi=10.1016/j.ijporl.2008.03.005|pmid=18433884|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0165587608001274|accessdate=27 November 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> there are Deaf communities around the world that use signed languages. Infants born to signing parents, or exposed immersively to fluent sign language models at a young age, generally acquire sign language natively.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
== Role of input and the environment == During the first year of life, all infants are primed to acquire information about the language in their environment.<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal|last=Kuhl|first=Patricia|date=2007|title=Cracking the speech code: How infants learn language|url=|journal=Acoustical Science and Technology|volume=28|pages=81|via=}}</ref><ref name="WerkerHensch-2015"">{{cite journal|last1=Werker|first1=Janet F.|last2=Hensch|first2=Takao K.|date=3 January 2015|title=Critical Periods in Speech Perception: New Directions|journal=Annual Review of Psychology|volume=66|issue=1|pages=173–96|doi=10.1146/annurev-psych-010814-015104|pmid=25251488|issn=0066-4308}}</ref> Deaf infants immersed in fluent [[sign language]] from birth develop native language skills in that sign language in the same manner as any other child acquiring a language natively.<ref name="Humphriesea-2012"">{{cite journal|last1=Humphries|first1=Tom|last2=Kushalnagar|first2=Poorna|last3=Mathur|first3=Gaurav|last4=Napoli|first4=Donna Jo|last5=Padden|first5=Carol|last6=Rathmann|first6=Christian|last7=Smith|first7=Scott R.|date=2 April 2012|title=Language acquisition for deaf children: Reducing the harms of zero tolerance to the use of alternative approaches|journal=Harm Reduction Journal|volume=9|pages=2–3|doi=10.1186/1477-7517-9-16|pmid=22472091|pmc=3384464|issn=1477-7517}}</ref><ref name="WoolfeEA-2010"">{{cite journal|last1=Woolfe|first1=Tyron|last2=Herman|first2=Rosalind|last3=Roy|first3=Penny|last4=Woll|first4=Bencie|date=1 March 2010|title=Early vocabulary development in deaf native signers: a British Sign Language adaptation of the communicative development inventories|journal=Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry|language=en|volume=51|issue=3|pages=329–330|doi=10.1111/j.1469-7610.2009.02151.x|pmid=19843318|issn=1469-7610|citeseerx=10.1.1.426.9105}}</ref><ref name="PfauEA-2012">{{cite book|title=Sign Language : An International Handbook|last1=Pfau|first1=Roland|last2=Steinbach|first2=Markus|last3=Woll|first3=Bencie|date=2012|publisher=De Gruyter Mouton|isbn=978-3-11-020421-6|location=Berlin|page=677}}</ref> The early experience of deaf children, however, is highly variable and frequently atypical from a [[language acquisition]] ===Deaf children born to deaf parents===
About three percent of deaf children are born to two deaf parents, with one percent born to one hearing and one deaf parent.<ref name=Mitchell-2004>{{cite journal |journal=Sign Language Studies |last=Mitchell |first=Ross E. |last2=Karchmer |first2=Michaela |title=Chasing the Mythical Ten Percent: Parental Hearing Status of Deaf and Hard of Hearing Students in the United States |jstor=26190985 |date=2004 |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=138–163 |issn=0302-1475 |doi= |access-date=}}</ref>{{rp|153, 155}}
==Deaf children born to hearing parents==
About 96% of deaf children are born to hearing parents.<ref name=Mitchell-2004 />{{rp|153, 155}} The majority of these children receive hearing aids and/or cochlear implants, and are taught to listen and to use spoken language using these devices. Research shows that deaf children who listen and speak to communicate, but do not use sign language have better communication outcomes<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Shani|last1=Dettman|title=Communication Outcomes for Groups of Children Using Cochlear Implants Enrolled in Auditory-Verbal, Aural-Oral, and Bilingual-Bicultural Early Intervention Programs|journal=Otology & Neurotology|date=2013|volume=34|issue=3|pages=451–459|doi=10.1097/mao.0b013e3182839650|pmid=23442569}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Ann|last1=Geers|title=Early Sign Language Exposure and Cochlear Implantation Benefits|journal=Pediatrics|date=2017|volume=140|issue=1|pages=e20163489|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-3489|pmid=28759398|pmc=5495521}}</ref> and social well-being<ref>{{cite journal|first1=Lone|last1=Percy-Smith|title=Factors That Affect the Social Well-Being of Children with Cochlear Implants|journal=Cochlear Implants International|date=2008|volume=9|issue=4}}</ref> than Deaf children who use sign language.
== Early stages (birth to 12 months) == The general stages of [[language acquisition]] are the same whether the language is spoken or signed.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Sign language : An international handbook|last=Pfau|first=Roland|last2=Steinbach|first2=Markus|last3=Woll|first3=Bencie|publisher=De Gruyter Mouton|others=|year=2012|isbn=9783110204216|location=Berlin|pages=647|oclc=812574063}}</ref> There are certain unique features of sign language acquisition due to the visual/manual [[Modality (semiotics)|modality]] and these differences can help to distinguish between universal aspects of language acquisition and aspects that may be affected by early experience.<ref name=":2" />
The very earliest linguistic tasks facing newborns are perceptual.<ref name=":32"/> Babies need to determine what basic linguistic elements are used in their native language to create words (their [[Phonetics|phonetic]] inventory). They also need to determine how to segment the continuous stream of language input into phrases and eventually words.<ref name=":72"/> From birth, they have an attraction to patterned linguistic input, which is evident whether the input is spoken or signed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Petitto|first=Laura Ann|last2=Marentette|first2=P|date=1991|title=Babbling in the manual mode: Evidence for the ontogeny of language|pmid=2006424|journal=Science|volume=251|issue=5000|pages=483–1496|via=}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Stone|first=Adam|last2=Petitto|first2=Laura Ann|last3=Bosworth|first3=Rain|date=December 2017|title=Visual Sonority Modulates Infants' Attraction to Sign Language|url=http://petitto.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Visual-sonority-modulates-infants-attraction-to-sign-language.pdf|journal=Language Learning and Development|volume=|pages=1–19|via=}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Petitto|first=Laura Ann|last2=Zatorre|first2=Robert J.|last3=Gauna|first3=Kristine|last4=Nikelski|first4=E. about the structure of their native language, particularly [[Prosody (linguistics)|prosodic]] and [[Phonology|phonological]] features.<ref name=":32" /> Sign languages have natural prosodic patterns and infants are sensitive to these prosodic boundaries even if they have no specific experience with sign languages.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brentari|first=Diane|last2=González|first2=Carolina|last3=Seidl|first3=Amanda|last4=Wilbur|first4=Ronnie|date=January 2011|title=Sensitivity to Visual Prosodic Cues in Signers and sign experience also preferentially attend to sign language stimuli over complex gesture, indicating that they are perceiving sign language as meaningful linguistic input.<ref>{{Cite Research shows that Deaf parents with deaf infants are more successful than hearing parents at capturing moments of [[joint attention]] when signing, which are privileged language learning moments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Spencer|first=Patricia|last2=Harris|first2=Margaret|date=2006|title=Patterns and effects of language input to deaf infants and toddlers from deaf and hearing mothers|url=|journal=Advances in the Sign Language Development of Deaf Children|volume=|pages=71–101|via=}}</ref> Deaf mothers are more adept at ensuring that the infant is visually engaged prior to signing<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harris|first=M.|date=2001-07-01|title=It's All a Matter of Timing: Sign Visibility and Sign Reference in Deaf and Hearing Mothers of 18-Month-Old Children|url=https://academic.oup.com/jdsde/article/6/3/177/454612|journal=Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education|language=en|volume=6|issue=3|pages=177–185|doi=10.1093/deafed/6.3.177|pmid=15451848|issn=1081-4159}}</ref> and use specific modifications to their signing, referred to as child-directed sign<ref name=":52">{{Cite journal|last=Pizer, Meier|first=G, R|date=2008|title=Pizer, G., & Meier, R. Just as in child-directed speech ([[Baby talk|CDS]]), child-directed signing is characterized by slower production, exaggerated prosody, and repetition.<ref name=":52" /> Due to the unique demands of a visual language, child-directed signing also includes tactile strategies and relocation of language into the child's line of vision.<ref name=":52" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meadow-Orlans|first=Kathryn P.|date=1997-01-01|title=Effects of Mother and Infant Hearing Status on Interactions at Twelve and Eighteen Months|url=https://academic.oup.com/jdsde/article/2/1/26/451567|journal=The Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education|language=en|volume=2|issue=1|pages=26–36|doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.deafed.a014307|issn=1081-4159}}</ref>
== Methods == === Pedagogy ===
Language acquisition strategies for signing deaf children are different than those appropriate for hearing children, or for deaf children who successfully use hearing aids and/or cochlear implants. For parents with deaf children who do not use amplification (hearing aids or cochlear implants), [[joint attention]] (an important component to language development) can be problematic. Hearing children can watch their environment and listen to an adult comment on it. However, children who do not hear have to switch their visual attention back and forth between stimuli.
Strategies for nonverbal communication include using facial expressions and body language to show emotion and reinforce the child's attention to their caregiver. To attract and direct a deaf child's attention, caregivers can break his line of gaze using hand and body movements, touch, and pointing to allow language input. In order to make language salient,{{clarify|reason=salient language?|date=February 2018}} parents should use short, simple sentences so that the child's attention doesn’t have to be divided for too long. Finally, to reduce the need for divided attention, a caregiver can position themselves and objects within the child's visual field so that language and the object can be seen at the same time.
=== Speech and oral methods ===
For deaf children who use listening and spoken language as their primary mode of communication, their families will often participate in [[Auditory-verbal therapy]], a means of enhancing the innate language and listening skills of deaf children. Most children who receive appropriate amplification before the age of 18 months and receive appropriate auditory-verbal instruction will follow language-learning trajectories of their peers who have typical hearing.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Niparko |first1=John |author1link=John Niparko |last2=Tobey |first2=Emily |last3=Thal |first3=Donna |title=Spoken Language Development in Children Following Cochlear Implantation |journal=JAMA |date=April 21, 2010 |volume=303 |issue=15 |pages=1498–1506 |doi=10.1001/jama.2010.451|pmid=20407059 |pmc=3073449 }}</ref>
=== Signing and manual methods ===
==== ASL (American sign language) ====
[[ASL]] employs signs made by moving one's hands along with one's facial expressions and body language. Some studies indicate that if a deaf child learns sign language, he or she will be less likely to learn spoken languages because they will lose motivation.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} However, Humphries insists that there is no evidence for this.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Humphries|first=Tom|last2=Kushalnagar|first2=Poorna|last3=Mathur|first3=Gaurav|last4=Napoli|first4=Donna Jo|last5=Padden|first5=Carol|last6=Rathmann|first6=Christian|last7=Smith|first7=Scott R.|date=2012-01-01|title=Language acquisition for deaf children: Reducing the harms of zero tolerance to the use of alternative approaches|journal=Harm Reduction Journal|volume=9|pages=16|doi=10.1186/1477-7517-9-16|issn=1477-7517|pmc=3384464|pmid=22472091}}</ref>
==== Manually coded English ====
[[Manually coded English]] is any one of a number of different representations of the English language that uses manual signs to encode English words visually. Although MCE uses signs, it is not a language like ASL; it is an [[encoding]] of English that uses hand gestures to make English visible in a visual mode. Most types of MCE use signs borrowed or adapted from American Sign Language, but use English sentence order and grammatical construction.
Numerous systems of manually encoded English have been proposed and used with greater or lesser success. Methods such as [[Signed English]], [[Signing Exact English]],<ref name="Kong-2008">Kong, W. W., & Ranganath, S. (2008). Signing exact english (see): Modeling and recognition. Pattern Recognition, 41(5), 1638-1652.</ref> [[Linguistics of Visual English]], and others use signs borrowed from ASL along with various grammatical marker signs, to indicate whole words, or meaning-bearing [[morphemes]] like ''-ed'' or ''-ing''.
Because MCE systems are encodings of English which follow English word order and sentence structure, it's possible to sign MCE and speak English at the same time. This is a technique that is used in order to teach deaf children the structure of the English language not only through the sound and lip-reading patterns of spoken English, but also through manual patterns of signed English. Because of the close connection between the two, it is easier for hearing people to learn MCE than ASL.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
==== Cued speech ====
[[Cued Speech]] is a hybrid, oral/manual system of communication used by some deaf or hard-of-hearing people. It is a technique that uses handshapes near the mouth ("cues") to represent phonemes that can be challenging for some deaf or hard-of-hearing people to distinguish from one another through speechreading ("lipreading") alone. It is designed to help receptive communicators to observe and fully understand the speaker.
Cued speech is not a signed language, and it does not have any signs in common with ASL. It is a kind of augmented speechreading, making speechreading much more accurate and accessible to deaf people. The handshapes by themselves have no meaning; they only have meaning as a cue in combination with a mouth shape, so that the mouth shape 'two lips together' plus one handshape might mean an 'M' sound, the same shape with a different cue might represent a 'B' sound, and with a third cue might represent a 'P' sound.
Some research shows a link between lack of phonological awareness and reading disorders, and indicate that teaching cued speech may be an aid to phonological awareness and literacy.<ref name=Ostrander-1998>{{cite web |url=http://web.syr.edu/~clostran/literacy.html |dead-url=yes |title=The Relationship Between Phonological Coding And Reading Achievement In Deaf Children: Is Cued Speech A Special Case? |first1=Carolyn |last1=Ostrander |date=1998 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113162758/web.syr.edu/~clostran/literacy.html |archivedate=2007-11-13 |accessdate=2018-02-11}}</ref>
==== Fingerspelling ====
Another manual encoding system used by the deaf and which has been around for more than two centuries is [[fingerspelling]]. Fingerspelling is a system that encodes letters and not words or morphemes, so is not a manual encoding of English, but rather an encoding of the alphabet. As such, it is a method of spelling out words one letter at a time using 26 different handshapes. In the United States and many other countries, the letters are indicated on one hand<ref>Carmel, Simon (1982). ''International hand alphabet charts.'' [[National Association of the Deaf (United States)]]; 2nd edition. (June 1982). {{ISBN|0-9600886-2-8}}</ref> and go back to the deaf school of the [[Abbe de l'Epee]] in Paris. Since fingerspelling is connected to the alphabet and not to entire words, it can be used to spell out words in any language that uses the same alphabet; so it is not tied to any one language in particular, and to that extent, it is analogous to other letter-encodings, such as [[Morse code]], or [[Semaphore]]. The [[Rochester Method]] relies heavily on fingerspelling, but it is slow and has mostly fallen out of favor.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
=== Hybrid methods ===
Hybrid methods use a mixture of aural/oral methods as well as some visible indicators such as hand shapes in order to communicate in the standard spoken language by making parts of it visible to those with hearing loss.{{unreferenced section|date=May 2018}}
{{empty section|date=September 2018}}
=== Literacy === {{unreferenced section|date=February 2018}}
==== Reading ====
According to Goldin-Meadow, reading requires two essential abilities: familiarity with a language and understanding the mapping between that language and the written word. However, reading is possible if deaf children learn ASL. Once they have acquired ASL, deaf children learn how to map between sign language and print so that they can learn English. Several techniques are used to help bridge the gap between ASL and spoken language or the "translation process" such as sandwiching and chaining.
Sandwiching consists of alternating between saying the word and signing it. Chaining consists of finger spelling a word, pointing to the spoken language version of the word and using pictorial support. Although chaining is not widely used, it creates an understanding between the visual spelling of a word and the sign language spelling of the word. This helps the child become bilingual in both ASL and spoken language.
The deaf child's social context is crucial for nurturing his or her capacity to read. Research shows that deaf children born to deaf parents are usually better readers than deaf children born to hearing parents.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} This is because deaf parents provide a strong social and emotional network and may immediately have access to the necessary resources for their child. Deaf parents already anticipate the needs of their child, having been through the same experience, as opposed to a hearing parent.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
== Cochlear implants== A [[cochlear implant]] is placed surgically inside the cochlea, which is the part of the inner ear that converts sound to neural signals. There is much debate regarding the linguistic conditions under which deaf children acquire spoken language via cochlear implantation. Some studies have concluded that long-term use of sign language impedes the development of spoken language and reading ability in deaf and hard of hearing children, and that using sign language is not at all advantageous, and can be detrimental to language development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Geers|first=A. E.|last2=Moog|first2=J. S.|last3=Biedenstein|first3=J.|last4=Brenner|first4=C.|last5=Hayes|first5=H.|date=2009-07-01|title=Spoken Language Scores of Children Using Cochlear Implants Compared to Hearing Age-Mates at School Entry|url=https://academic.oup.com/jdsde/article/14/3/371/329991|journal=Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education|language=en|volume=14|issue=3|pages=371–385|doi=10.1093/deafed/enn046|pmid=19155289|issn=1081-4159}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Shani|last1=Dettman|title=Communication Outcomes for Groups of Children Using Cochlear Implants Enrolled in Auditory-Verbal, Aural-Oral, and Bilingual-Bicultural Early Intervention Programs|journal=Otology & Neurotology|date=2013|volume=34|issue=3|pages=451–459|doi=10.1097/mao.0b013e3182839650|pmid=23442569}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Ann|last1=Geers|title=Early Sign Language Exposure and Cochlear Implantation Benefits|journal=Pediatrics|date=2017|volume=140|issue=1|pages=e20163489|doi=10.1542/peds.2016-3489|pmid=28759398|pmc=5495521}}</ref> However, studies have found that sign language exposure actually facilitates the development of spoken language of Deaf children of Deaf parents who had exposure to sign language from birth. These children outperformed their deaf peers who were born to hearing parents following cochlear implantation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hassanzadeh|first=S.|date=2012|title=Outcomes of cochlear implantation in deaf children of deaf parents: comparative study|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-laryngology-and-otology/article/outcomes-of-cochlear-implantation-in-deaf-children-of-deaf-parents-comparative-study/A949F20D96D996073FBB47590F4F85F2|journal=The Journal of Laryngology & Otology|language=en|volume=126|issue=10|pages=989–994|doi=10.1017/S0022215112001909|pmid=22906641|issn=0022-2151|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davidson|first=K.|last2=Lillo-Martin|first2=D.|last3=Pichler|first3=D. Chen|date=2014-04-01|title=Spoken English Language Development Among Native Signing Children With Cochlear Implants|url=https://academic.oup.com/jdsde/article/19/2/238/377174|journal=Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education|language=en|volume=19|issue=2|pages=238–250|doi=10.1093/deafed/ent045|pmid=24150489|issn=1081-4159|pmc=3952677}}</ref>
===Ethics and language acquisition===
Cochlear implants have been the subject of a heated debate between those that believe deaf children should receive the implants and those that do not. Members of the Deaf Community believe this is an important ethical problem. They strongly advocate that sign language is their first or native language just as any other spoken language is for a hearing person. They do not see deafness as a deficiency in any way, but rather a normal human trait amongst a variety of different ones. One issue on the ethical perspective of implantation is the possible side effects that may present themselves after surgery (the body may physically reject the implant; for some reason, there may not be any benefit, or very little gained; the internal component may need to be replaced causing the need for another surgery), even in some cases lessening listening capabilities, losing residual hearing or hearing sounds differently. While the surgery presents one positive solution, these side effects are not often taken into account but are significant and need to be afforded more attention. However, complications from cochlear implant surgery is a rare event, with some centers showing less than a three percent failure rate.{{cite web|url=https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/239926.php|title=Cochlear Implant Failure Rate Generally Low}}
== Relationship between language acquisition and other domains of development ==
=== Cognitive development === Early exposure to language facilitates language acquisition, regardless of whether or not that exposure is native or non-native, as well as many other domains of development, such as cognitive development, including executive functioning skills. Executive functioning skills are extremely important, as these are the skills that guide learning and behavior<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Hall|first=Matthew L.|last2=Eigsti|first2=Inge-Marie|last3=Bortfeld|first3=Heather|last4=Lillo-Martin|first4=Diane|date=2016-09-13|title=Auditory Deprivation Does Not Impair Executive Function, But Language Deprivation Might: Evidence From a Parent-Report Measure in Deaf Native Signing Children|url=https://academic.oup.com/jdsde/article/22/1/9/2744719|journal=Journal of Deaf Studies and Deaf Education|language=en|volume=22|issue=1|pages=9–21|doi=10.1093/deafed/enw054|pmid=27624307|pmc=5189172|issn=1081-4159}}</ref>. These skills include self-regulation, inhibition, emotional control, working memory, and planning and organization, which contribute to overall social, emotional and academic development for children. Early access to a language, such as sign language, from birth supports the development of these cognitive skills and abilities in Deaf and hard of hearing children, and supports their development in this area<ref>{{Cite journal|date=2003-12-01|title=Age constraints on first versus second language acquisition: Evidence for linguistic plasticity and epigenesis|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0093934X03001378|journal=Brain and Language|language=en|volume=87|issue=3|pages=369–384|doi=10.1016/S0093-934X(03)00137-8|issn=0093-934X|last1=Mayberry|first1=Rachel I.|last2=Lock|first2=Elizabeth}}</ref>.
However, late exposure to language and delayed language acquisition can inhibit or delay the cognitive development of deaf and hard of hearing children, and impact these skills. This late exposure to language, or lack thereof, can be defined as language deprivation (see [[Language deprivation in deaf and hard of hearing children]]). This experience is the result of a lack of exposure to natural human language, whether that be spoken or signed language, during the critical language period<ref name=":02" />. Approximately 90% of Deaf children are born to hearing parents, and 95% of those Deaf children experience language deprivation to some degree<ref name=":02" />. Language Deprivation has been found to impair deaf children’s cognitive development, specifically their executive functioning skills, and working memory, causing deficits in critical executive functioning skills and overall cognitive development.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Marshall|first=Chloë|last2=Jones|first2=Anna|last3=Denmark|first3=Tanya|last4=Mason|first4=Kathryn|last5=Atkinson|first5=Joanna|last6=Botting|first6=Nicola|last7=Morgan|first7=Gary|date=2015|title=Deaf children's non-verbal working memory is impacted by their language experience|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|language=English|volume=6|pages=527|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2015.00527|pmid=25999875|pmc=4419661|issn=1664-1078}}</ref>. It is not deafness that causes these deficits, but late language acquisition that influences the cognitive development and abilities of deaf people.<ref name=":12" />
=== Social-emotional development === <p>Having an acquired language means an individual has had full access to at least one spoken or signed language.Typically, if a person has had this full access to language and has been able to acquire it, then being able to enter into a realm of social and emotional becomes plausible. Being able to communicate using is critical for those still developing their social skills<ref name=":22">{{Cite web|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/140.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAZ4wggGaBgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggGLMIIBhwIBADCCAYAGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMFh5pQJvI5m7dR_GxAgEQgIIBUQWnPtWmmWaPBeEiz0cUJNT8WZgv874iQ6cl-7oN1u8Ktoi4ri0FwtVMhiNbIFiEu7aR1pI_jcWOV6ZYOY55gnxEP0sk3npoEW_faTEwZtE3Gjsc9rHx5OWwUf6rjKwY7eZ4CeyyfNus6W-WQm93NtINR4pEV8GRPV3A3h2yfj0x-ifP4_PSjXOJ6Z_f-YOgP2wGMSZMeC-DqQ8msacRllYRbbF0sVeDJjg-Owxo-r2DdGtEc3UTPRAEftiOi1Psp-bpIcF-tlfyUtXOnUkOKH6YiIh2ba9Sly2SSmfCYal2oUZsVCpZ-qE67_3uUN5CrPmso9eCCCDKJqol9LvkU_9P_Lqib3R8sAErjQoetJk70-HfjrgDKd4idBF3NvrgTI1y6udZw187mJin7tRM4OJSMmF85OqfvBACkU179KmsMSX48QVP51b5GszvMPSOUX8|title=Parental Involvement in Deaf Children's Education Programs as a Predictor of Child's Language, Early Reading, and Social- Emotional Development|last=Calderon|first=Rosemary|date=2000|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. There is also evidence to suggest that language acquisition can play a critical role in developing [[Theory of mind|Theory of Mind]], or developing the understanding of false beliefs in language<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schick|first=Brenda|last2=de Villiers|first2=Peter|last3=de Villiers|first3=Jill|last4=Hoffmeister|first4=Robert|date=2007-03|title=Language and Theory of Mind: A Study of Deaf Children|journal=Child Development|language=en|volume=78|issue=2|pages=376–396|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2007.01004.x|pmid=17381779|issn=0009-3920|citeseerx=10.1.1.473.8685}}</ref>. For children who have been deprived of this access or have not yet fully acquired a language, social development can be hindered, which in turn can affect one’s emotional development as well.</p>The lack of socialization can significantly impact a child’s emotional well-being. A child’s first experience with social communication typically begins at home, but deaf and hard of hearing children in particular who are born to hearing parents tend to struggle with this interaction, due to the fact that they are a “minority in their own family"<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ME5q-42NojgC&pg=PA177&dq=social+emotional+development+%22deaf+children%22,+Moores,+2001#v=onepage&q=social%20emotional%20development%20%22deaf%20children%22,%20Moores,%202001&f=false|title=Oxford Handbook of Deaf Studies, Language, and Education|last=NEWSOM|first=CAROL|last2=Newsom|first2=Professor of Old Testament Carol A.|date=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195149975|language=en}}</ref>. Parents who have a Deaf child typically do not know a signed language, the logistical problem can become how to give that child a full language. If deaf and hard of hearing children are not developing their social skills at home, by the time they enter school, they can be behind in this development. All of this can lead to struggles with proper emotional development. It can be hard on a child who was not given a language early to try and express their emotions appropriately. The problem is not with the deaf child, but instead, not giving a deaf or hard of hearing child the necessary language access from birth that other children receive<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ME5q-42NojgC&pg=PA177&dq=emotional+deaf+children+#v=onepage&q=emotional%20deaf%20children&f=false|title=Oxford Handbook of Deaf Studies, Language, and Education|last=NEWSOM|first=CAROL|last2=Newsom|first2=Professor of Old Testament Carol A.|date=2003|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195149975|language=en}}</ref>. There are theories to suggest that language acquisition is a predictor of how a child can develop Theory of Mind and without a full language, this skill becomes null. Theory of Mind can be an indicator of social and cognitive development. Without language acquisition, Deaf children can become behind in Theory of Mind and the skills that coincide, which can lead to further social and emotional delays.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Schick|first=Brenda|last2=de Villiers|first2=Peter|last3=de Villiers|first3=Jill|last4=Hoffmeister|first4=Robert|date=2007-03|title=Language and Theory of Mind: A Study of Deaf Children|journal=Child Development|language=en|volume=78|issue=2|pages=376–396|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2007.01004.x|pmid=17381779|issn=0009-3920|citeseerx=10.1.1.473.8685}}</ref>
=== Academic development === Second language acquisition is also highly affected by early language exposure<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Kroll et al.|date=2015|title=Bilingualism, Mind, and Brain|url=|journal=Annual Review of Linguistics|volume=1|pages=377–394|via=Annual Reviews|pmid=28642932|pmc=5478196|doi=10.1146/annurev-linguist-030514-124937}}</ref>. More exposure in an accessible language leads to better performance in the second language upon entering school<ref name=":3" />. Providing deaf and hard of hearing children with the most language exposure possible from birth promotes both first and second language acquisition. This means giving students the opportunity to develop language at home and in social environments early on supports the child's language acquisition in American Sign Language as well as printed English<ref name=":22" />. There is extensive research regarding the correlation between proficiency in ASL and proficiency in English literacy skills<ref name=":42">{{Cite journal|last=Cummins|first=Jim|date=2006|title=The Relationship between American Sign Language Proficiency and English Academic Development: A Review of the Research|url=|journal=Research Gate|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>.{{Verify source|date=May 2018}}. Deaf students with higher ASL proficiency tend to have higher English reading and writing scores<ref name=":42" />. There is also research to support that the development of a second language also improves proficiency in the student's first language<ref name=":3" />
According to Hrastinski & [[Ronnie Wilbur|Wilbur]] (2016), American Sign Language proficiency is the single most contributing factor to Deaf student’s academic achievement, particularly in reading literacy and math.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://watermark.silverchair.com/env072.pdf?token=AQECAHi208BE49Ooan9kkhW_Ercy7Dm3ZL_9Cf3qfKAc485ysgAAAaMwggGfBgkqhkiG9w0BBwagggGQMIIBjAIBADCCAYUGCSqGSIb3DQEHATAeBglghkgBZQMEAS4wEQQMS3camrsCwizIKhRSAgEQgIIBVpFuCm23QV_wHVAF3qVgbdg62eoEq1JZsJzomxbO32RncjGo5NWdeLlsU9FuynA2gSKh0AmiGnxZbZZTlHY_7pXQ-hiftLjL9eDTOfd3ZjUbfJmfcS15UDVJ1MTCiBrZukQfXeLsILvWEB4vfub0AoAbauMv9_DJI_g_gwToj0mPihM_xeoxSZ8-ol7ZoHV8nHQ_2B88eVr-zbdCzQvcPSfuAFVi-6a1o_G0R1AFAXIdoCpkobHaTGZNZpWS2LYyjZu6ROohCwka4zTyQm3bZUH4cavd5Eex0uGq67odjR3Q3wWsUB2KnmIfYC0ZBBRhBZl0UDp7glaYAeXhKXQVAm4HsR5VdFOAVUCKF-c9zY_wLIX07ANiGjyQJRBbDYl8gs0Bau5w4oD77V_WYsbZZcbJedA2IjGAVtcZUmBJioWxxHKSeEbIZAdBpwfmLGUkgl-GTlbmUw|title=Academic Achievement of Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Students in an ASL/English Bilingual Program|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. Deaf and hard of hearing children who have higher levels of American Sign Language proficiency and those who have higher proficiency in a second language (e.g., English) are those who were exposed to American Sign Language during the critical period of language.<ref name=":6" />
